questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever, cough, cold, and respiratory rate was 46/min. According to the WHO guidelines, which of the following, if present, is not considered a danger sign in this baby?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, it can be inferred that the child has pneumonia. Chest indrawing is not considered a danger sign in this baby.

 Danger signs of pneumonia in children are: 

  • Not able to drink 
  • Persistent vomiting 
  • Convulsions, lethargic or unconscious 
  • Stridor in a calm child 
  • Severe malnutrition 

 Pneumonia diagnosis is as given in the table below:

Age of child Fast breathing RR
<2 months  >60 breaths/min
2-12 months  >50 breaths/min
1-5 years  >40 breaths/min

 The revised classification of acute respiratory infections is simplified to include only two categories of pneumonia:

  • pneumonia- with fast breathing and/or chest indrawing, which requires home therapy with oral amoxicillin.
  • severe pneumonia- pneumonia with any general danger sign, which requires a referral and injectable therapy.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presented with ascending left-sided flank pain during micturition and recurrent episodes of urinary tract infections. The urologist suspects vesicoureteric reflux. Which of the following investigations can be done to confirm this condition?

DMSA: Dimercapto succinic acid
questions.solution:
A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) can be done to confirm vesicoureteric reflux.

Vesicoureteric reflux is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder back to the ureter and kidney. The condition is usually congenital and familial. It is more commonly seen in females during evaluation for a urinary tract infection. It predisposes the child to pyelonephritis resulting in renal injury or scarring. This is known as reflux-related renal injury or reflux nephropathy.

The international reflux study (IRS) classification divides it into grades I-V based on the severity as shown below. This is based on the appearance seen in contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

Recurrent urinary tract infections are commonly seen in cases with grade III or IV vesicoureteric reflux. The condition is diagnosed by a voiding cystourethrogram. This is done by catheterization of the bladder followed by instillation of an iodinated contrast. Vesicoureteric reflux done during voiding is known as high-pressure vesicoureteric reflux. A low-dose radiation contrast VCUG provides anatomic information such as a duplex collecting system, ectopic ureter, and bladder diverticulum.

The image below shows dilated ureters seen in a case of vesicoureteric reflux.

Antibiotic prophylaxis and behavioral modification can be used for management. Surgical correction can be done laparoscopically or by the endoscopic route. It should be considered in cases of recurrent acute pyelonephritis despite antibiotic therapy and in the presence of surgically correctable malformations.

Other options:

Option A: A DMSA scan can be done to assess the degree of renal scarring. DMSA renal scan will show photopenic areas bilaterally indicating acute pyelonephritis and renal scarring.

Options B and D: An ultrasound and MRI are not required to diagnose vesicoureteric reflux.

questions.text: You are a pathology resident who is looking at a slide, showing small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes as shown below. The history you received from the pediatric surgery resident was that the specimen was resected from a 5-year-old child with ataxia. The tumor was present in the midline vermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and slide are suggestive of Medulloblastoma. 

Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, occurring predominantly in the cerebellar vermis that causes ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. It may cause obstructive hydrocephalus and often metastasizes extraneurally.

Histopathology shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells and is characterized by Homer–Wright rosettes and an immunopositivity for synaptophysin. 

Standard treatment for medulloblastomas is surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy.
Prognosis is strongly influenced by surgical resection, the presence of CSF metastases at the time of diagnosis, and the expression of the c-erbB-2 (HER2/neu) oncogene.

Note: Small, round, blue-cell tumors are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. It consists of sheets of small round cells that stain blue on routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Examples are:

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

A new study shows that children with medulloblastoma who were treated with radiotherapy had better intellectual outcomes when the radiation was delivered as proton beam therapy compared to traditional photon radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text:
Which among the following disorders does not follow the classic mendelian inheritance?
  1. Angelman syndrome
  2. Marfan syndrome
  3. Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  4. Prader -Willi syndrome
  5. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, Angelman syndrome (1), Kearns-Sayre syndrome (3), and Prader-Willi syndrome (4) do not follow a classic Mendelian inheritance pattern.

The non-mendelian inheritance pattern is used to describe mitochondrial inheritance, trinucleotide repeat disorders, and genetic imprinting.

Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome arise due to genetic imprinting. Here, the gene expression depends on the parental origin of the chromosome. It results due to an imbalance in the active copies of a specific gene. In Angelman syndrome, the maternal copy is affected while the paternal one is affected in Prader-Willi syndrome. Both the syndromes present with developmental delays and mental retardation. 

Kearns-Sayre syndrome is a mitochondrial disorder that results in lactic acidosis, pigmentary retinitis, and progressive external ophthalmoplegia. 

The classic forms of genetic inheritances such as autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, and X-linked inheritance are referred to as Mendelian inheritance forms.

Autosomal dominant inheritance is marked by the presence of one abnormal gene on one of the autosomes/ chromosomes 1-22. Autosomal recessive inheritance requires both copies of the same to be abnormal. If genes located on the X chromosome are affected, an X-linked pattern of inheritance with males being affected more commonly is seen. 

Other Options:

Option 2: Marfan's syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Features include tall stature, arachnodactyly, lens subluxation, and aortic root dilatation. 

Option 5: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder that is characterized by the involvement of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs. Calf hypertrophy is a characteristic feature.

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text: An 8-day-old neonate presents with yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera. Which of the following may not be a cause of neonatal jaundice that appears after the first week of life?
questions.solution:
Erythroblastosis fetalis causes neonatal jaundice and manifests within the first 24 hours of life, not after 1st week.

Jaundice in the first 24 hours of life requires immediate attention and can be due to erythroblastosis fetalis, concealed hemorrhage, sepsis, or congenital infections, including syphilis, cytomegalovirus, rubella, and toxoplasmosis. Jaundice appearing on the 2nd or 3rd day of life is usually physiologic but also can be due to early onset breastfeeding jaundice and Crigler-Najjar syndrome (familial non-hemolytic icterus). Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 3rd day but within the 1st week of life can be due to bacterial sepsis, urinary tract infections or other infections like syphilis, etc.

Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 1st week of life can be due a number of conditions like breast milk jaundice, congenital atresia or paucity of bile ducts, hepatitis, cystic fibrosis, hemolytic anemia, enzyme deficiencies etc.

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. Continuation of breastfeeding exclusively resolves most of the cases.

questions.text:
During your neonatal rotation, a final year student asks you to explain the score which evaluates the baby at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth. Which among the following is an incorrect statement regarding it?
  1. 1 point is assigned if the baby is pink with blue extremities
  2. 0 points are assigned if the baby is floppy
  3. 2 points are assigned if the pulse is absent 
  4. 1 point is assigned if the respiratory rate is less than 40
  5. 2 points if the baby coughs in response to the insertion of a nasal catheter
questions.solution:
The score which evaluates the baby at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth is the APGAR score, and statements 3 and 4 are incorrect.

The Apgar score is a method of systematically evaluating newborn infants immediately after birth. It measures appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration. It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.

Statements 3 and 4 are incorrect because 0 points are assigned if the pulse is absent, and respiratory rate is not used in calculating the APGAR score, but the respiratory effort is considered.

The maximum score is 10 which indicates the fetus is in the best possible condition. Scores of 0-3 require immediate resuscitation, although resuscitation should ideally be started before the  1-minute APGAR score is calculated. 

APGAR score can be used to assess the response to resuscitative efforts and should be calculated every 5 minutes for up to 20 minutes if the 5-minute Apgar score is less than 7.

Causes of Low APGAR scores include:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Analgesics, narcotics, sedatives
  • Airway obstruction (Eg: choanal atresia)
  • Pneumonia and sepsis
  • Previous episodes of fetal asphyxia (recovered)

False-negative APGAR score is when the score is normal, but there is acidosis or high fetal catecholamine levels.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy last vaccinated at 12 weeks of life presents to you with a high-grade fever, cough, and a rash. The parents say that the rash shown below started from the forehead and behind the ears, and then it spread to the neck and body. Which of the following is true regarding this child's condition?
  1. Causative agent is an RNA paramyxovirus
  2. The secondary attack rate in susceptible contacts is ≥90%
  3. Forchheimer spots are characteristic
  4. Jeryl Lynn strain of vaccine is used for prevention
  5. Most complications are due to secondary bacterial infections.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the symptoms, incomplete vaccination history, and regional distribution of the red maculopapular rash is suggestive of measles. Options 1,2 and 5 are correct regarding this condition.

Measles is caused by a single-stranded, lipid-enveloped RNA paramyxovirus. Contact with large droplets or small-droplet aerosols is the route of transmission. Infection results in respiratory tract epithelial necrosis and lymphocytic infiltration. Clinical features include high fever, cough, coryza, and a rash.

Koplik spots appear 1-4 days before the onset of the rash. They appear as discrete red lesions with bluish-white spots at the level of the premolars. It can also involve the lips and gingiva. This is followed by the appearance of the rash that starts on the forehead, neck, and behind the ears. It then spreads to involve the torso and extremities. The image below shows Koplik's spots.

Confirmation of the diagnosis can be made by IgM assay. Affected children need to be isolated for 4 days after the beginning of the rash to prevent its spread. Management is mainly supportive by the maintenance of hydration and oxygenation. 

Most complications are secondary to bacterial infections. Pneumonia is the most common cause of death and acute otitis media is the most common complication. Croup, bronchiolitis, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis are the other complications.

Secondary attack rates in susceptible contacts are usually ≥90%. Vaccination against measles is the most effective way to prevent the condition. It is contraindicated in individuals with severe immunosuppression.

Rubella, also known as German measles is a viral disease that presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, rash, and lymphadenopathy. Forchheimer spots are tiny rose-colored lesions or petechial hemorrhages seen on the soft palate. It is usually seen with the onset of the rash. The rash starts on the face and neck and then involves the torso and extremities. It is shown in the image below. 

The Jeryl Lynn strain of virus is used for vaccination against mumps. It is a systemic viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus characterized by parotitis.

Related Pearl: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine: 

  • Type: Live attenuenated, lyophilized (freeze dried), vaccine (Tissue culture vaccine- chick embryo or Human diploid cell line).

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV and liquid pentavalent vaccine.

It is not applicable for BCG, measles, rotavirus vaccines and JE vaccines.

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be use in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water.

Ensure all opened vials have recorded date and time of opening.

At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable.

All open vials of BCG, measles and JE must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete.

All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register.

Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text:
On ultrasound, a fetus was found to have intrauterine growth restriction, with the head circumference relatively preserved compared to length and weight. This type of growth restriction would have occurred due to all of the following causes except

TORCH: Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, such as syphilis or hepatitis B, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, Herpes simplex
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), which would have been caused by all the above conditions except TORCH infections, which cause symmetric IUGR.

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) refers to a deficiency of fetal growth and an abnormal fetal growth trajectory. It is often classified as 

Symmetric IUGR:

  • Insult on fetal growth occurs early.
  • As a result, head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected.
  • It can be due to genetic causes, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections in the fetus.

Asymmetric IUGR

  • Insult occurs in late gestation, producing a relative brain-sparing effect.
  • The Head circumference is relatively preserved compared to weight and length.
  • It is caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension(PIH), poor maternal nutrition, or maternal medical diseases (option A,B and C)

Severe maternal hypertension causes symmetric IUGR while late-onset maternal vascular disease(PIH, preeclampsia) causes asymmetric IUGR.

questions.text: A teacher complains that a 7-year-old girl with falling grades is inattentive in class and has unresponsive episodes with staring. On hyperventilation, her symptoms increase and her EEG findings show a 3Hz spike and wave discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child who is inattentive in class and has unresponsive episodes with staring with EEG showing a 3Hz spike and wave discharge is suggestive of typical absence seizures.

Absence seizures are a form of generalized seizures marked by unresponsiveness, staring, and eye flutter which usually last for a few seconds. GABAB receptors, T-type Ca2+ channels, and K+ channels situated within the thalamus are involved in the pathophysiology of absence seizures.

It is of two types:

  • Typical absence seizures  
  • Atypical absence seizures  

Typical absence seizures are associated with 3-Hz spikes and slow wave discharges on EEG. It usually starts by the age of 5-8 years and can occur up to a hundred times per day. Hyperventilation can precipitate seizures and EEG changes. They last only for a few seconds and do not have an aura. It can be accompanied by eyelid flutter or upward rolling of the eyes. Simple automatisms such as lip smacking or picking at clothing can also be seen. There is no postictal period and the child usually resumes whatever activity he/she was engaged in prior to the episode. 

Atypical absence seizures are associated with 1-2-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges. Head atonia and myoclonus can also be seen during the seizures. It is precipitated by drowsiness and is generally more difficult to treat. 

Juvenile absence seizures occur at a later stage and are similar to typical absences. It is marked by 4-to-6 Hz spike-and-slow-wave and polyspike-and-slow-wave discharges. It is associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

EEG is the diagnostic test for absence seizures. An MRI would appear normal and so is not useful. Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for typical absence seizures. Its mechanism of action is the inhibition of T-type calcium channels. Phenytoin, carbamazepine, and oxcarbazepine have all been associated with aggravation of absence seizures and even absence status epilepticus in children with absence epilepsy.

The following epilepsy syndromes are associated with the absence seizures:

  • Childhood absence epilepsy
  • Juvenile absence epilepsy
  • Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy
  • Myoclonic absence epilepsy
  • Lennox-gestaut syndrome

Other options:

Option A: Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. It is marked by the rapidity of jerks (<50 mseconds). EEG changes depend on the type of myoclonic seizure.

Option B: Myoclonus is very brief, abrupt, and involuntary jerky contractions of a single muscle or muscle group. Some causes of myoclonus in children include hiccups (physiologic), meningitis, and electrolyte disturbances.  

Option D: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy also known as Janz syndrome is a type of generalized epilepsy seen in young adults. It presents as myoclonic jerks in the morning and generalized tonic-clonic or clonic-tonic-clonic seizures upon awakening. Sleep deprivation and photic stimulation can precipitate the episodes. 4-5 Hz polyspike-and-slow-wave discharges can be seen on EEG.

questions.text: An anxious mother is worried about feeding her baby. The baby was born at 29 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. What will you advise as a routine primary feeding method for this baby?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a baby born at 29 weeks of gestation and 2 kg birth weight, nasogastric tube feeding can be advised as a routine primary feeding method.

The feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age and it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate. In this scenario, as the baby is 2 kg (low birth weight) and was born at 29 weeks of gestation, nasogastric tube feeding is preferred. Babies born before 32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai feeding can only be used occasionally. Babies born after 34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern and breastfeeding is more preferred.

Based on birth weight, babies can be classified into

  • Low birth weight (LBW) - Birth weight < 2.5kg
  • Very low birth weight (VLBW)- Birth weight <1.5kg
  • Extremely low birth weight (ELBW)- Birth weight <1kg

All LBW infants, irrespective of their initial feeding method should receive only breast milk. This can be given as expressed breast milk (mothers' own milk) to those infants fed by paladai or gastric tube. An alternative is human donor milk. When there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick, formula feeds can be given. Term formula feed in babies with birth weight >1500 g and preterm formula feed in VLBW babies can be given. All hemodynamically stable LBW babies should receive Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC).

LBW can result from preterm birth (born before 37 completed weeks) IUGR (intrauterine growth restriction) or both. Prematurity and low birth weight are the leading causes of neonatal mortality.

questions.text: A mother has brought her 6-month-old infant to a pediatrician for a regular checkup. She tells her baby's weight was approximately double the birth weight at 5 months of age. The baby's weight would be approximately triple the birth weight by the age of:
questions.solution:
The baby's weight would be approximately triple the birth weight by the age of 1 year.  

Infant weight approximately doubles by the age of 5 months, triples by 1 year, and is 4 times by 2 years of age. Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life as a result of excretion of excess extravascular fluid and limited nutritional intake. They regain their birth weight by their 2nd week and thereafter gain weight at specific rates at specific age groups.

The growth and development of a child between the age of 6-12 months can be classified as:

  • Physical Development:  By 12 months of age, birth weight has tripled, length has increased by 50%, and head circumference has increased by 10 cm. A mature pincer grasp occurs and tooth eruption has started to occur. Motor achievements correlate with increasing myelinization and cerebellar growth.
  • Cognitive Development: Object permanence appears by 9 months of age. The baby tries to search for a hidden object.
  • Emotional Development: Infants may cling or cry anxiously when a stranger approaches, demonstrating stranger anxiety. Separation anxiety can also seen.
  • Linguistic Development: Between 8 and 10 months of age, infants produce multisyllabic sounds (“ba-da-ma”) called canonical babbling. Babies can discriminate between languages.

  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant who was born at term was presented with complaints of lethargy and poor feeding. On examination, the infant had a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, and protruding tongue, as shown below. The lower limb x-ray revealed an absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism.

The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism include a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, protruding tongue, prolonged jaundice, lethargy, and a history of poor feeding. The absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses denotes the onset of congenital hypothyroidism. These epiphyses are normally present at birth.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability. Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India accounting for about 75% of all cases.

Congenital hypothyroidism is mostly asymptomatic at birth and is detected mainly by the neonatal screening of TSH levels in the first few weeks of life. Clinical features present after maternal thyroxine wanes.

Screening is usually done on day 2-day 4 postnatally, and usually, dried blood samples are used for this. The most commonly used strategy is screening for TSH first, as they have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based screening.

In untreated hypothyroidism, as the child grows older, there is a discrepancy between chronological age and osseous development. Epiphyseal dysgenesis wherein there are multiple foci of ossification in the epiphyses, is common. X-rays of the skull reveal large fontanelles, wide sutures, and intersutural (wormian) bones. Radiotracer uptake study with radioactive iodine or technetium should be done as soon as primary congenital hypothyroidism is diagnosed.

Treatment with levothyroxine should be started within 2 weeks in order to maintain normal cognitive and physical development. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve the normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. 

Other options:

Option A- Down’s syndrome also presents with developmental delay and hypothyroidism. They have characteristic facial features such as a flat face, depressed nasal bridge, upslanting palpebral fissures, and a single palmar crease. The image shown below depicts an infant with Down's syndrome. Radiological features include atlantoaxial dislocation.

Option B-  Congenital rickets is a rare condition resulting from severe maternal vitamin D deficiency and can present with symptomatic hypocalcemia, intrauterine growth retardation, decreased bone ossification along with classic rachitic changes.

Option D- Hurler's syndrome is a mucopolysaccharidosis which may present after 6 months with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.

  2. Image 2                  B. TAPVC

TAPVC: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, and 4-B.

Image 1  C. Tetralogy of Fallot
Image 2  D. Transposition of great arteries
Image 3 A. Ebstein's anomaly
Image 4 B. TAPVC

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)  is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by a tetrad of:

  1. Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  2. Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  3. Aorta overriding VSD
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy

In TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. This on X-rays appears as a boot-shaped heart or Coeur en sabot.

Transposition of great arteries (TGA) is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Because of this, the pulmonary and systemic circulations remain separate. The cardiac silhouette usually has an egg-on-side appearance due to cardiomegaly and a narrow mediastinum. Normal to increased pulmonary blood flow is also seen. 

Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by the downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. In some cases, there can be massive cardiomegaly resulting in a box-shaped heart. 

Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins instead of joining to the left atrium resulting in pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium. In supracardiac TAPVC the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resemble a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was examined in a village camp. The child had a poor appetite and visible peripheral edema. The hair was sparse and easily pluckable. The skin showed peeling as shown below.  What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette of a child with poor appetite, sparse easily pluckable hair, and the image showing flaky paint dermatosis are suggestive of Kwashiorkar.

Kwashiorkor results due to severe protein and essential amino acid deprivation along with adequate calorie intake. It is particularly seen in children at the time of weaning, to a diet consisting majorly of corn, rice, or beans. 

The clinical features include a classic cutaneous finding of diffuse reddish-brown scaling dermatosis that has been likened to cracked skin, peeling paint, enamel paint, flaky paint, or crazy paving. This is due to the typical scaling and irregular fissuring. Nails are thin and soft. Hairs are thin and sparse and display a flag sign consisting of alternative light and dark bands of hair. The consistent feature is peripheral edema due to the associated hypoproteinaemia. Edema of the face results in moon facies. Abdominal distention (pot belly) is a feature and is due to hepatomegaly from increased fatty deposition due to a lack of available apolipoproteins.

Other options:

Option A: Marasmus results due to global macro-nutrient deficiency, which leads to growth retardation with <60% of ideal body weight. Loss of subcutaneous tissue, growth stunting, dyspigmentation, and desquamative changes are seen in these patients. Marasmus patients do not demonstrate hypoproteinaemia or edema. There is distension of the abdomen due to hypotonia of the abdominal musculature. These patients typically have wrinkled, loose, and dry skin. The hair and nails often grow slowly and may show brittleness. The hair falls out easily and often shows features of alopecia.

Below is the image of a child with marasmus.

Option B: Pellagra results from a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). It is characterized by the classic presentation of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Casal's necklace is a lesion seen around the neck, which is a characteristic feature seen in pellagra.

Below is the image showing Casal's necklace.

Option C: Vitamin A deficiency can result in phrynoderma that is characterized by keratotic follicular papules along the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral arms. It is seen in the deficiency of vitamin B complex, C, E, and essential fatty acids as well.

Below is the image showing phrynoderma.

questions.text: A 10-day-old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is hyper-alert with normal EEG. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes, mydriatic pupil, and clonus.  What stage of HIE is she in?
questions.solution:
According to Sarnat staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), a hyperalert neonate with mydriatic pupil, hyperactive tendon reflex, clonus, and normal EEG belongs to stage 1. 

HIE is a brain injury that prevents adequate blood supply to the infant's brain. 

Sarnat staging of HIE:

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity

Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hours if progress it; otherwise, can remain normal 24 hours to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits

Maternal causes for HIE are hypoventilation during anesthesia, cyanotic heart disease, respiratory failure, or carbon monoxide poisoning. Failure of oxygenation due to severe anemia, massive blood loss, and intracranial or adrenal hemorrhages are fetal causes of HIE. 

Hypoxia and ischemia cause anaerobic metabolism that generates a large amount of lactate and inorganic phosphates accumulation of toxic byproducts and overactivation of receptors. This leads to increased cellular permeability to sodium and calcium ions, resulting in cytotoxic edema and neuronal death. The most sensitive imaging modality for detecting hypoxic brain injury in neonates is an MRI.

Therapeutic hypothermia within the first 6 hours of life reduces mortality and major neurodevelopmental impairment. High-dose erythropoietin is used as an adjuvant to therapeutic hypothermia. Antiepileptic medications like phenobarbital and levetiracetam can be used to treat seizures. 

 Poor prognostic factors in HIE are:

  • Initial blood ph less than 6.7
  • Low (0-3) 10  in Apgar score
  • Delayed onset of spontaneous breathing
  • Seizure onset in less than 12 hours
  • Burst suppression pattern in EEG
  • Basal ganglia or thalamic lesion
  • Oliguria or anurias for more than 24 hours
  • Decerebrate posture

questions.text:
Arrange the following milestones in the order of their development.

1. Sits in the tripod position

2. Waves bye-bye

3. Bidextrous reach

4. 8-10 words vocabulary
questions.solution:
The correct order of development of the milestones given is 3-1-2-4.

Development in a child is the maturation of functions and skills for optimal functioning of an individual. Developmental milestones are easily identifiable events that occur during the developmental process. It is assessed under the following domains.

  • Gross motor
  • Fine motor
  • Personal and social development
  • Language

A baby will reach out for objects with both hands, also known as bidextrous reach by the age of 4 months. It is a key fine motor milestone. 

A child is able to sit with his arms forward for support, known as the tripod position at around 6-7 months. The ability to sit without any support develops by 8 months. It is part of gross motor development. 

By around 9 months, the baby can wave bye-bye. He/she also repeats any activity that can get an appreciative response from the observers. It is a social and adaptive milestone.

By the age of 18 months, the baby has a vocabulary of 8-10 words. By the age of 2, increases to 100 words which can be joined to form simple sentences.

questions.text:
Match the following metabolic derangements with their most likely presentations -
  Metabolic derangement   Clinical presentation
A. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency 1. Splenomegaly, avascular necrosis, and delayed puberty
B. Beta-galactosidase deficiency 2. Copious nasal discharge, corneal clouding, dysostosis multiplex
C. Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency 3. Hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, doll-like facies
D. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase 4. Extreme irritability, developmental delay, optic atrophy
    5. Hepatomegaly, vomiting, cataracts, and sepsis
questions.solution:
The correct match is A-3, B-4, C-2, and D-5.

A. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is seen in Von Gierke disease which is a glycogen storage disorder (Type Ia). Patients with GSD Type I present with a protruding abdomen due to hepatomegaly, doll-like facies, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, organomegaly, seizures, and pulmonary hypertension. It is an autosomal recessive disorder 

B. Beta-galactosidase deficiency is seen in Krabbe's disease which is a lysosomal storage disorder. It is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from the deficiency of galactocerebrosidase. The classic manifestations that would suggest Krabbe's disease include irritability, seizures, and hypertonia.  Optic atrophy and developmental delay are other features.

C. Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency is seen in Hurler syndrome,  a type of mucopolysaccharidosis type I.  Infants develop characteristic coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, inguinal hernias, and typical skeletal abnormalities, known as dysostosis multiplex. Corneal clouding, short stature, and copious nasal discharge are other features.

D. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency is seen in classical galactosemia. Clinical features include jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and sepsis. They also tend to develop cataracts.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. Red cell distribution width is normal.  The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and peripheral blood smear showing target cells and aniso-poikilocytosis, along with the normal red cell distribution width(RDW), are suggestive of thalassemia.

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-Thalassemia arises due to the deficient synthesis of β-chains. Normal adult RBCs have HbA, along with HbA2 and fetal haemoglobin (HbF) in small amounts. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. 

α-Thalassemia is caused by deficient synthesis of α-chains. It can also present as an α-thalassemia trait, with trivial hematologic abnormalities. Excess of β- and γ-globin chains form Bart hemoglobin (γ4) in fetal life and HbH (β4) after birth. Severe deficiency leads to hydrops fetalis.

Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to bone marrow hyperplasia and extramedullary hematopoiesis, which can involve the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. In β-thalassemia major, anemia manifests 6 to 9 months after birth. HbF levels are markedly elevated. The presence of bony anomalies such as frontal bossing, prominent facial bones, and dental malocclusion is typical.

The image below shows thalassemic facies (frontal bossing and maxillary hyperplasia) in a child with thalassemia major. 

Laboratory findings: Infants with severe β-thalassemia diseases experience increasing anemia following the newborn stage. The RBCs exhibit microcytosis, hypochromia, and target cells. Usually observed are nucleated RBCs, a distinct anisopoikilocytosis, and relative reticulocytopenia. Without transfusions, the Hb level frequently drops to 6 g/dL in a gradual manner.

The RDW shows the size difference in the red blood cells. Low RDW means all the red blood cells are small and uniform in size, while a large RDW means that the cells vary in size. It is normal in case of thalassemia as all cells are uniformly small in size. It increases in iron deficiency anaemia because of presence of small and normal sized RBCs.

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) confirms the diagnosis of thalassemia. It shows the absence of HbA and high levels of HbF.

Other options:

Option A: Glossitis, stomatitis, darkening of the skin on the knuckles and terminal phalanges, and enlargement of the liver and spleen are characteristics of megaloblastic anemia. Peripheral smear in megaloblastic anemia is characterized by macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils (shown below).

Option B: Iron deficiency anemia has high RDW. Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia along with target cells.

Option D: Megaloblastic anemia has a particular subtype called pernicious anemia. It is caused by insufficient vitamin B12 absorption through the gastrointestinal pathway, leading to vitamin B12 insufficiency. Macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils are frequent observations in the peripheral smear associated with megaloblastic anemia. Neutrophil hypersegmentation is an early symptom of the disease and typically occurs beyond 3 to 5 lobes.

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A junior radiologist performing a fetal doppler follows the direction of the flow of oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus to examine the fetal circulatory vessels. The sequence that he would follow is:

choices.text: Umbilical artery → inferior vena cava → ductus venosus → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical artery → superior vena cava → right atrium → ductus arteriosus → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus arteriosus → superior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium

questions.solution:
The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior venacava → right atrium → left atrium.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with sudden onset of high-grade fever, seizures,  and loss of consciousness. On examination, the child had anaemia, hypoglycemia, and no neurological deficits. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
This scenario depicts a case of cerebral malaria due to a severe complicated falciparum infection.

Severe complicated malaria is caused by Plasmodium falciparum and is characterized by jaundice, severe anaemia, respiratory distress, bleeding manifestation, cardiovascular collapse, renal failure and cerebral malaria.

Cerebral malaria is diagnosed in the case of P. falciparum parasitemia with altered consciousness. Common features include seizures and hypoglycemia. Retinal haemorrhages, neurological findings like hemiplegia, absent or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and a positive Babinski sign can also be seen.

All patients with severe malaria should be treated with intravenous or intramuscular artesunate for at least 24 hours.

Meningitis has fever accompanied by lethargy, irritability, signs of meningeal irritation like the Kernig sign-flexion of the hip 90 degrees with subsequent pain with extension of the leg, and Brudzinski sign-involuntary flexion of the knees and hips after passive flexion of the neck while supine. Increased ICP is suggested by headache, emesis, bulging fontanel or widening of the sutures, oculomotor (anisocoria, ptosis) or abducens nerve paralysis, hypertension with bradycardia, apnea or hyperventilation, stupor, coma, or signs of herniation. A lumbar puncture is essential to obtain CSF for Gram stain and culture, which is the most important step in the diagnosis of meningitis.
